messageBody:
Stirling, Scott wrote:

> > From: Curt Sampson [mailto:yahoo_sucks@...]
> >
> > I've seen
> > situations where you end up with a few smart guys doing all the work,
> > and a few "grunts" sitting around that can't do anything, because they
> > don't have the technical sophistication to do anything but duplicate
> > code that's already in the system, making more work, not less, for the
> > senior folks.
>
> Yes. I've seen this too. I call them "riveters" since I've been
> reading a book on the design and construction of the Empire State
> Building and the analogy seems apt. The riveters don't design or do
> anything sophisticated -- they just rivet together the beams that you
> tell them to.

I find it hard to believe that this works. It just seems like a huge
waste. One talented programmer does the work of five not-so-talented
ones at 60% of the price (of the five).

> > In my current project, we don't even have any dedicated QA people; the
> > programmers themselves are responsible for doing all of the
> > QA. We ended up with a very heavily automated solution, one we never
> > could have had without QA staff who were programmers to the point that
> > they could change our software internals to make it more testable.
>
> Sounds cool.

Hm. Do you mean that you don't have people who test full time? or you
don't have people will formal testing experience and/or raw testing skill?

Google "What is exploratory testing?"
